titleStmt.title: Receipt [194-195 AD?]
titleStmt.author: Horigenes, son of Ischyrion, secretary of the cultivators

msContents.summary: Horigenes acknowledges the receipt of a sum of money collected from the farmers of Theadelphia and paid over to the epiteretes and sitologoi of Apias for the value of lentils; the transaction was witnessed by a police officer

msItemStruct.note: Written along the fibers; the back is blank; papyrus worn and with holes
16 lines of writing by a proficient hand which is slightly irregular
The text suggests that Apias was more prominent as center for collection of taxes than Theadelphia
This transaction was probably exceptional; there are no exact parallels
The date is uncertain as a result of the loss of the bottom part

supportDesc.support: 1papyrus fragment, broken at bottom ; 13.9 x 11.2 cm

provenance.p: Purchased by Columbia University from Dr. Askren through H.I. Bell in 1924; no. 40 in Bell's inventory

taxonomy.desc: APIS keywords are controlled locally at the institution level. They are not necessarily consistent.

keywords.term: Eudaimon, -- son of Theogiton, tax collector
Sokrates a.k.a. Theon, -- son of Heron, sword-bearer

div.ab: Horigenes, son of Ischyrion, secretary of the cultivators of the village of Theadelphia, to Eudaimon, son of Theogiton, epiteretes in the same village, greetings. I have received from you, in silver, the sum of two thousand five hundred drachmas and thirteen obols, total 2500 dr. 13 ob., that you had received from the cultivators of the public and imperial land of the village, and which sum, in the presence of the sword-bearer Socrates, also called Theon, son of Heron, also called Lourios, went to Isidoros, son of Horion, epiteretes at Apias and to the sitologoi as for the price of lentils; total of the above-mentioned, 2500 dr. 13 ob. I, the aforesaid Horigenes, have written (this document). Year three . . .

listBibl.bibl: P.Col. X 268 Plate 22 in P.Col. X; published by J.-J. Aubert, BASP 24 (1987) 125-36
